problem.para: For each of the statements below indicate if it is true or false.
The rank of a system of linear equations is the number of 1’s in the non-augmented coefficient matrix of the system.

solution.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is the number of leading 1’1 in the RREF of the non-augmented coefficient matrix of the system. This number of leading 1’s is normally unrelated to the number of 1’s in the non-augmented coefficient matrix of the original system.
Therefore the statement in question is false.

problem.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is the number of 1’s in the RREF of the coefficient matrix of the system.

solution.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is the number of leading 1’1 in the RREF of the non-augmented coefficient matrix of the system. This number of leading 1’s is normally less than the number of 1’s in this RREF.
Therefore the statement in question is false.

problem.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is the number of leading 1’s in the RREF of the non-augmented coefficient matrix of the system.

solution.para: This statement is exactly the definition of the ‘rank of a system of linear equations’. Therefore this statement is true.

problem.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is always equal to the number of variables in the system.

solution.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is the number of leading 1’s in the RREF of the non-augmented coefficient matrix of the system. This number of leading 1’s can be less than the number of variables in the system.
Therefore the statement in question is false.

problem.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is always greater than the number of variables in the system.

solution.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is the number of leading 1’s in the RREF of the non-augmented coefficient matrix of the system. This number is always less than or equal to the number of variables in the system.
Therefore the statement in question is false.

problem.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is always less than the number of variables in the system.

solution.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is the number of leading 1’s in the RREF of the non-augmented coefficient matrix of the system. This number can be equal to the number of variables in the system.
Therefore the statement in question is false.

problem.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is always less than or equal to the number of variables in the system.

solution.para: Indeed, the rank of a system of linear equations is the number of leading 1’s in the RREF of the non-augmented coefficient matrix of the system.
Therefore the statement in question is true.

problem.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is always greater than or equal to the number of variables in the system.

solution.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is the number of leading 1’s in the RREF of the non-augmented coefficient matrix of the system. This number can be less than the number of variables in the system.
Therefore the statement in question is false.
